sentences_tone.text: Zynga: You Don't Have To Wait For A Price Rise To Make Money - Zynga (NASDAQ:ZNGA) | Seeking AlphaSign in / Join NowGO»Market NewsStock IdeasDividendsMarket OutlookInvesting StrategyETFs & FundsEarningsPROLong IdeasShort IdeasCramer's PicksIPOsQuick PicksSectorsEditor's PicksZynga: You Don't Have To Wait For A Price Rise To Make MoneyNov.
4.16 | About: Zynga (ZNGA) Nikhil Gupta Follow Growth at reasonable price, contrarian, medium-term horizon, macroSend MessageSummaryInvestors in Zynga may benefit from using option-based strategies.
Covered call and short strangle can help the investors earn massive returns.
It is not necessary to wait for a stock price appreciation to make money.
Zynga (NASDAQ: ZNGA) released the Q3 earnings report yesterday.
While I am not too impressed with the results, the market is taking it positively as the stock trades with a gain of 4.20 percent at $2.85.

However, since the stock has gone sideways in the last two years, investors have employed a simple buy low and sell high strategy, making money repeatedly and essentially lowered their average purchase prices.
Some were lucky enough to break even and exited this gaming stock.

Click to enlarge Source: TradingView As can be seen from the weekly ZNGA price chart above, the stock is trading close to the higher-end of the broad range and is facing selling pressure and profit booking.
The stock is also taking support from the 30-week SMA of $2.6965.
Several reasons can be attributed to the stock's strong performance today.
The reasons have almost subdued the disappointment from the weak Q4 guidance doled out by the management after-hours yesterday.
First and the foremost factor that is driving the positive sentiment today is the announcement of a share repurchase program valid through October 2018-end.
In this program, shares worth up to $200 million will be repurchased, and will be funded by the available cash or other sources of funding.
However, there is no guarantee that any shares will be purchased.
As of September 30, 2016, Zynga had cash and marketable securities of $871 million, compared to $868 million as of June 30, 2016.
Second, the company reported a strong free cash flow growth, both on QoQ and YoY basis.
At the end of Q3, the company generated free cash flow of $18.36 million, which stood at $13.25 million at the end of Q2 and at ($6.63) million in the same period a year ago.
The strong fcf performance was aided by an equally strong operational cash flow.
The company's operations provided $21 million at the end of Q3'16, compared to $14.56 million at the end of Q2'16, and ($5.11) million in the comparable period a year ago.
Click to enlarge But, this may not be enough to take the stock out of its two-year trading range.

If it breaks out on the upside, then investors will have a good chance at exiting their long positions because this is definitely not a business to hold for the long-term given the attitude and the actions of the management.
If it does not, then investors should have another option at their disposal.
And this option should be low-risk yet profitable.
I would recommend two options strategies to ZYNGA investors - Covered Call and Short Strangle.
If you are unaware of these terms, don't worry.
These are just some fancy names but if properly employed, can provide hefty returns to the investors.
I will discuss both the strategies one by one, and discuss the rewards and the risks involved with each.
Covered Call This is a very simple strategy and is most applicable to those investors who feel they purchased their ZNGA shares a bit too high.
The basic premise of recommending this strategy is to generate returns simultaneously even as the stock languishes in its own trading range.
In fact, the resilience of the stock to oscillate in this trading range is what makes this a compelling strategy to use.
Another helpful factor to consider when employing this strategy is to take the beta of the stock into consideration.

It is most helpful when the expectation regarding a stock is neutral-to-slightly-bullish in the period considered, and hence, an investor holds the stock long while earning a premium on his sold call option.
For Zynga, I am looking at the January 2018 options chain, and I am interested in the $4 strike price call option.
Investors can try out other option chains as well as different strike prices.
It can be seen that the $4 call option last traded at $0.25 and the bid is of $0.21 while the ask is of $0.46.
Now, this is an Out Of The Money (OTM) option, which means that the current stock price is well below this strike price.
The current odds of this call expiring worthless is a strong 66%.
This means that the market believes that there is a 66% chance that the stock will not close above $4 on January 19, 2018.
These odds are calculated using the basic building blocks of options called the Option Greeks.
If you are well-versed with these, then they can prove to be very helpful.
If not, then again, there is no need to worry.
Keeping the strategy in perspective, if an investor were to sell this call option, he would receive a premium of $0.25 (last traded price).
The higher he can sell it for, the bigger premium he can take.
Therefore, the bid-ask spread is essential.

It also means that it is important that an investor sell this call option when the stock is rising in order to bag a higher premium and when there is reasonable assurance that the rally will not last long.
Click to enlarge Source: StockOptionsChannel Note: I am not discussing commissions and fees to make the calculations simpler.
An investor must confirm with his broker regarding the margin requirements and the fees involved before opting for this strategy.
Assuming for a moment that the stock fails to close above $4 on the expiration date, the investor will reap a reward of (premium) + (price on the expiration day - today's price).
Suppose that the stock ends at $4.00 on expiry, then the maximum return that an investor will enjoy is ($0.25)
This translates into a massive return of 49 percent in the next 442 days or 40.46 percent annualized.
If the stock were to drop down to say $2.50, the investor would have a reduced and easily manageable loss of ($0.25) + $(2.50-2.85)
= $0.10 or 3.53 percent.
The maximum loss that an investor can incur is the money invested in shares - the premium received on selling the option.
Short Strangle If the above strategy didn't impress, then this one should probably do the trick.
A short strangle is a strategy that works best when little volatility is expected in the stock.
Zynga serves our purpose well with a low beta of 0.28.
The strategy involves selling out of the money call options and out of the money put options of the same expiration date.
Considering that we are still short $4 call option, we will now be raking in additional premium by selling the $2 put option.
This is because the market is of the opinion that on the stock will not close below $2 on the expiry date, which is the same as the call option.
The market currently puts the odds of the put option expiry worthless at a massive 81%.

Click to enlarge Source: StockOptionsChannel Even more interesting, and helpful, to us is the fact that for the same premium available of $0.25 (Last = 25 cents), the probability is significantly higher than that of the call option.
This means that the market is also slightly bullish for ZNGA as of this moment.
But, it is a very long period and a lot of things could change in the meantime.
So, the total expected premium that an investor can reasonably expect now is $0.25 (from $4 call) + $0.25 (from $2 put) = $0.50.
If the stock stays in the range of $2-$4, then he stands to make a very easy profit of $0.50/$2.85
= 17.54%, which annualizes to 14.5 percent.
Not too shabby, I guess.
This would also protect an investor from a limited downside at the end of the period.
The major risk in this strategy is that if the stock relentlessly breaks down and goes below the $2, just like it did in February this year, and does not rebound to close above $2 by expiry.
In that case, the investor will incur a dual loss from a decline in share price as well as a rising put option value, which he will have to pay for.
For the put option, his risk will emerge if the stock slides below $1.75 ($2-$0.25).
On a positive note, this strategy lends protection in whichever direction the stock chooses to move.
Conclusion Zynga investors do not necessarily have to wait for higher share prices to make a profit.
They can do so by efficiently employing the two option strategies discussed above after confirming the commissions charged by their brokers.
I have deliberately omitted the commissions to make the calculations easier to understand.
Option strategies can sometimes be hard to understand, and therefore, an investor must give some time and consideration to understand the risks and rewards involved in them properly.
Zynga, being a low beta, is a good candidate to employ the covered call and short strangle strategies which can provide low-risk income to the investors.
It essentially saves an investor from years of waiting to close out the position at a breakeven or at a profit or at reduced losses.
Note: I cover several stocks in different sectors as well as S&P 500, crude oil, gold and silver, U.S. dollar, etc.
